intro: Saponaria esfandiarii, commonly known as the Persian soapwort, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Iran. It belongs to the carnation family (Caryophyllaceae) and is characterized by its clusters of pink or white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features hairy, lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a suitable choice for rock gardens or borders. Saponaria esfandiarii is also noted for its historical use in traditional medicine and as a source of natural soap.
